I stopped caring about someone's pedigree after that case
We settled for $1

Judge re-reviews the cases Ivy Attorney had handed up. Ivy Attorney sputters some nonsense. Judge then re-examines my on-point-af case law that he'd previously ignored.

👨🏻‍⚖️: "How about I give y'all some time to resolve this?"

And I go "I am *totally* lost, Judge. I thought this was a Rule 60 hearing. But all of Mr. Ivy Attorney's arguments and case law are on Rule 59. And I'm still new so I don't know if this is a normal thing here or what."
So the Judge looks at me, and goes "Mr. Doucette you seem lost. Is everything ok?"

He's arguing Rule 59 (amending judgments). All of his fantastic-for-him case law is on Rule 59.

Our motion was under Rule 60.
We get back there, and it dawns on me Ivy Attorney doesn't know the Rules of Civil Procedure.
Judge sees my confusion and asks us back to chambers b/c he thinks I'm unprepared and he doesn't want to embarrass me on the record.
Intern is confused af too, b/c she knows the case and saw me argue the first time.

Second hearing on the same motion, in front of a new judge. Ivy Attorney beats me like a rented mule during oral arguments. With an intern watching. I'm confused af b/c the only thing that's changed in the case is the judge.

First hearing on the motion, Ivy Attorney sends New Associate to argue it. I mop the floor with him. But judge is brand new (only days on the bench) and doesn't want to decide it, so he continues the case.
The details are immaterial, but opposing counsel was a super-decorated Ivy Attorney (and a tremendous asshole). They'd gotten a default judgment before I was hired. I filed a motion to set it aside.
Reminds me of a case I had my first year of practice or so, that I'd dubbed the "stripper case" (client taught exotic dancing)
